channel.title: Clinical Machine Learning
channel.description: Recent content on Clinical Machine Learning

item.title: Research
item.description: .jumptarget::before { content:""; display:block; height:80px; /* fixed header height*/ margin:-80px 0 0; /* negative fixed header height */ } a.section{ color:#A31F34; } a:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color:#A31F34; } .section{ font-size: 1.2em; } Our lab is broadly interested in advancing machine learning and artificial intelligence, and using these to transform health care. Here we explain our three broad focus areas as well as representative papers. For more papers, see our publications section.

item.title: Publications
item.description: .bibbase_paper_title a { pointer-events: none; } /* remove bibbase link to authors with bibbase accounts */ a.bibbase.author.link { color: #333; text-decoration: none; pointer-events: none; cursor: default; }

item.title: Software
item.description: a {color: #A31F34;} For latest projects, see our Github. Example software includes: Deep Markov Models: Theano code for implementing Deep Markov Models using variational inference during learning to maximize the likelihood of the observed data Embeddings of Medical Concepts: Code for AMIA CRI 2016 paper “Learning Low-Dimensional Representations of Medical Concepts” Health Knowledge Graph: Learned Health Knowledge Graph from emergency room data as featured in Nature Scientific Reports

item.title: Contact Us
item.description:
a {color: #A31F34;} Email David’s email: dsontag {@ | at} mit.edu
FAQs How can I join the group as a Ph.D. student? As of Fall 2018, we are accepting Ph.D. students into the lab. Graduate admissions are handled at the department level at MIT, so please first apply to the MIT EECS and/or HST (Health Sciences and Technology, joint between MIT and Harvard Medical School) Ph.D. program.

item.title: Mission
item.description: Machine Learning Perspective Making ML work in high-stakes settings Recently developed techniques in machine learning have proven adept at solving problems in computer vision, natural language processing, board games, video games, and other domains where computers had previously struggled to outperform humans. However, deployment in high-stakes settings is still limited, for good reasons: Predictive models alone may be insufficient - we may care about causal questions (as in personalized medicine), not just predictive ones.

item.title: People
item.description: Our team consists of post-docs, students, research scientists, and clinical collaborators. For information about how to join us, see our FAQ section.
